items.fromString:
*Acceptance criteria:*

* When PSIwms is selected for deployment, you can choose the DBMS type for your deployment.
* There is documentation on how to choose the DBMS type.
* The DBMS options when deploying PSIwms include a PostgresQL database.
* Deploying PSIwms with PostgresQL database selected as its DBMS, an actual postgres is deployed, and no other DBMS is deployed.
* A finished deployment contains a PSIwms server that started up successfully.

*Unsure about these requirements:*

* Configuration and SpraKeys can be imported into the database via SPU.
items.toString:
To make PSIwms deployments via Helm charts useful for non-developers, too, we need to integrate it properly into existing deployment infrastructure.

Currently, this mostly means that we have to add the {{devops}} repository to ArgoCD, and then make sure that the images and Helm chart also work with the GKE cluster used by ArgoCD, instead of just locally.

*Acceptance criteria:*

* When PSIwms is selected for deployment, you can choose the DBMS type for your deployment.
* There is documentation on how to choose the DBMS type.
* The DBMS options when deploying PSIwms include a PostgresQL database.
* Deploying PSIwms with PostgresQL database selected as its DBMS, an actual postgres is deployed, and no other DBMS is deployed.
* A finished deployment contains a PSIwms server that started up successfully.

*Unsure about these requirements:*

* Configuration and SpraKeys can be imported into the database via SPU.

items.fromString: As a QA person, I want to deploy PSIwms with a postgres database
items.toString: As a QA person, I want to deploy PSIwms with a postgres database via ArgoCD

items.fromString:
*Acceptance criteria:*
 * When PSIwms is selected for deployment, you can choose the DBMS type for your deployment.
 * There is documentation on how to choose the DBMS type.
 * The DBMS options when deploying PSIwms include a PostgresQL database.
 * Deploying PSIwms with PostgresQL database selected as its DBMS, an actual postgres is deployed, and no other DBMS is deployed.
 * A finished deployment contains a PSIwms server that started up successfully.

*Unsure about these requirements:*
 * Configuration and SpraKeys can be imported into the database via SPU.
 * A PSIwms/postgres deployment contains at least one end-user client (Desktop, Mobile, Web) that is able to perform a booking.
 * Given a PSIwms/postgres deployment, you can perform a booking.
 * Given a PSIwms/postgres deployment, after performing a booking, the change can be reproduced reliably by viewing the results of the booking.

items.fromString:
*Info:* Desktop Client is not interesting. Only GO must work. Don't push it. Maybe use Sputest to create batches.

*Question* from [~accountid:5d70c7c16e3e1f0d9623f5dc]: Where is desktop client  running?

*Acceptance criteria:*
 * The user can see the login screen of a PSIwms Desktop Client for their PSIwms deployment.
 * The user can authenticate against PSIwms using this client.
 * An authenticated user can see the navigation menu in this client.
 * Following this sequence of actions results in a changed article description:
 ** 1.
 * The user can login to the PSIwms Desktop and see the menu.
 * It is possible to make a booking via PSIwms Desktop
 * The dialogs AUFBATSUM and TOUR are working correctly.
items.toString:
Although the PSIwms Desktop Client is gradually replaced by PSIwms Mobile and PSIwms Web Client, and {{sputest}} can be used to create batches for further processing with those clients, we still assume that we cannot do without Desktop completely yet.

Therefore, we want to make this client available for anyone who deploys their own instance of PSIwms using our Helm chart.

*Acceptance criteria:*
 * A PSIwms deployment contains a service that is responsible for serving the PSIwms Desktop Client to users, either
 ** as a download, or
 ** by making it available via HTTP with a technology like noVNC.
 * The user can see the login screen of a PSIwms Desktop Client for their PSIwms deployment.
 * The user can authenticate against PSIwms using this client.
 * An authenticated user can see the navigation menu in this client.
 * Following this sequence of actions results in a changed article description:
 ## Open PSIwm Desktop client.
 ## Open Dialog ART (shortcut upper left).
 ## Press button "F5 refresh" to load data.
 ## Click any of the shown entries.
 ## Press button F8 change.
 ## Change the article description in the upper right.
 ## Press OK.
 ## Press button "F5 refresh" to load data.

customfield_10020.name: DEVOPS Sprint 5
customfield_10020.goal: Prepare the team and all their resources for a smooth transition to Google Cloud

items.fromString:
Since floor workers in a warehouse cannot sit on a PC or other larger device permanently, they need a way to interact with PSIwms while "on the floor". There is a separate client for that: PSIwms Mobile (interchangebly: MDT or MDT4).

We extend the PSIwms deployment chart so that it also contains PSIwms Mobile as a separate service, just like the clients that we already added. A floor worker can just browse to an URL to open the client, authenticate and then do their work.

The client should be served by a web service, and then executed in the user's browser.

*Acceptance criteria:*
 * A PSIwms deployment contains a service that is responsible for serving PSIwms Mobile.
 * There is documentation for how to find the entry point of the Mobile client of a deployment in a browser.
 * Opening the client as documented results in a launch of the Mobile client.
 * It is possible to authenticate against PSIwms using this Mobile client.
 * An authenticated user can see the navigation menu in this Mobile client.

items.toString:
Since floor workers in a warehouse cannot sit on a PC or other larger device permanently, they need a way to interact with PSIwms while "on the floor". There is a separate client for that: PSIwms Mobile (interchangebly: MDT or MDT4).

We extend the PSIwms deployment chart so that it also contains PSIwms Mobile as a separate service, just like the clients that we already added. A floor worker can just browse to an URL to open the client, authenticate and then do their work.

The client should be served by a web service, and then executed in the user's browser.

*Acceptance criteria:*
 * A PSIwms deployment contains a service that is responsible for serving PSIwms Mobile.
 * There is documentation for how to find the entry point of the Mobile client of a deployment in a browser.
 * Opening the client as documented results in a launch of the Mobile client.
 * It is possible to authenticate against PSIwms using this client.

*Not sure how to handle these:*
 * It is possible to make a booking via PSIwms Mobile
 * These dialogs are working:
 ** [Automatic Transport|https://collaboration.psi-cloud.com/display/wmsdesdocutrunk/Automatic+Transport]
 ** [Change Location|https://collaboration.psi-cloud.com/display/wmsdesdocutrunk/Change+Location] 
 ** [Enter Return|https://collaboration.psi-cloud.com/display/wmsdesdocutrunk/Enter+Return]
 ** [Grade Return|https://collaboration.psi-cloud.com/display/wmsdesdocutrunk/Grade+Return]
 ** [Loading|https://collaboration.psi-cloud.com/display/wmsdesdocutrunk/Loading]
 ** [Picking Automatically|https://collaboration.psi-cloud.com/display/wmsdesdocutrunk/Picking+automatically]
 ** [Relocate Stock|https://collaboration.psi-cloud.com/display/wmsdesdocutrunk/Relocate+Stock]
 ** [Sorting|https://collaboration.psi-cloud.com/display/wmsdesdocutrunk/Sorting]
 ** [Unipack|https://collaboration.psi-cloud.com/display/wmsdesdocutrunk/Unipack]
 ** [WE Item Scan|https://collaboration.psi-cloud.com/display/wmsdesdocutrunk/WE+Item+Scan]

items.fromString:
Beyond [https://int-log-psise.atlassian.net/browse/DEVOPS-95|https://int-log-psise.atlassian.net/browse/DEVOPS-95|smart-link], we want to make PSIwms Web available in a deployment with PostgresQL instead of Oracle databases.

This story assumes that some database interaction is enough do showcase a working connection with postgres, and that any other problem that will arise in PSIwms Web after that is not caused by a deployment problem, but by a problem in PSIwms itself. If this assumption is wrong and there are actually functions that do not work with PSIwms Web/postgres due to deployment problems, a separate user story should be created for that later.

*NB:* The PSIwms Web client connects directly to the database, so it has to be able to handle postgres, too.

*Acceptance Criteria:*

* It is possible to deploy PSIwms with a PostgresQL database, see [https://int-log-psise.atlassian.net/browse/DEVOPS-111|https://int-log-psise.atlassian.net/browse/DEVOPS-111|smart-link].
* There is documentation on how to find the PSIwms Web service URL of a PSIwms/postgres deployment.
* Accessing the PSIwms Web service URL of a PSIwms/postgres deployment in a browser as documented launches PSIwms Web in that browser.
* There is documentation on how to authenticate as a user against PSIwms Web.
* An authenticated user can see the navigation menu in PSIwms Web.
* An authenticated user can see the a list of articles from the database in PSIwms Web.

items.fromString:
Running PSIwms Web requires a range of web services; we will not list those separately here. If the client works, we assume that the services are there, too.

For this story, we can reuse the existing Helm chart from DEVOPS-95, and hopefully only have to adapt some values.

*NB:* The PSIwms Web client connects directly to the database, so it has to be able to handle postgres, too.

*Acceptance Criteria:*
 * It is possible to deploy PSIwms with a PostgresQL database, see DEVOPS-111.
 * There is documentation on how to find the PSIwms Web service URL of a PSIwms/postgres deployment.
 * Accessing the PSIwms Web service URL of a PSIwms/postgres deployment in a browser as documented launches PSIwms Web in that browser.
 * There is documentation on how to authenticate as a user against PSIwms Web.

*Unsure about these:*
 * After authenticating against the PSIwms Web client of a PSIwms/postgres deployment as documented, the user can perform a booking.
 * After authenticating against the PSIwms Web client of a PSIwms/postgres deployment as documented, the user can query (which kind of?) data.

 * It is possible to deploy PSIwms with a PostgresQL database, see DEVOPS-111.
 * There is documentation on how to find the PSIwms Web service URL of a PSIwms/postgres deployment.
 * Accessing the PSIwms Web service URL of a PSIwms/postgres deployment in a browser as documented launches PSIwms Web in that browser.
 * There is documentation on how to authenticate as a user against PSIwms Web.

*Unsure about these:*
 * After authenticating against the PSIwms Web client of a PSIwms/postgres deployment as documented, the user can perform a booking.
 * After authenticating against the PSIwms Web client of a PSIwms/postgres deployment as documented, the user can query (which kind of?) data.

items.fromString:
PSI SE wants to evaluate as a whole if, and under which terms, we want to move to Google Cloud. For this purpose, a timeboxed evaluation project was started, called the GCP PoC: Google Cloud Platform Proof of Concept.

An overview of the project for all of PSI SE can be found [here|https://confluence.psi.de/display/OC/Google+Cloud+PoC].

For LOG, we want to lift&shift PSIwms to a GKE (Google Kubernetes Engine) cluster. PSIwms has never been deployed productively in containers yet, and we lack a lot of Kubernetes and cloud knowledge, so there's a lot of research involved. Specifics for the LOG part of the PoC can be found [here|https://confluence.psi.de/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=1144685492].
items.toString:
PSI SE wants to evaluate as a whole if, and under which terms, we want to move to Google Cloud. For this purpose, a timeboxed evaluation project was started, called the GCP PoC: Google Cloud Platform Proof of Concept.

For LOG, we want to lift&shift PSIwms to a GKE (Google Kubernetes Engine) cluster. items.fromString:
At first, check if Jenkins are able to connect to the IBM k8s cluster.

The Kubernetes plugin is already installed in Jenkins. Configure it to connect to the cluster.
[Kubernetes | Jenkins plugin|https://plugins.jenkins.io/kubernetes/]

Could be possible, that the credentials have to change every few days because of the refresh token in the ibm cluster - check whether the interval of the refresh token can be extended.
Otherwise we have to live with it until we switch to another cluster.

 

{*}Acceptance Criteria{*}:
- Jenkins is connected with the cluster via the plugin (Test connection is successfull)
items.toString:

items.fromString:
When building docker images on jenkins, I get an error, files that are required by dockerfile cannot be found.

The problem is this line of code:

```
docker build -t \$image_name -f \$dockerfile .
```
A potential solution is to set the context to the dockerfile folder:
```
docker build -t \$image_name -f \$dockerfile $(dirname "\$dockerfile")
```
Additionally, consider excluding the entire apps folder when building images

items.fromString:
As a dev in this team, I want to automate building Docker images on k8s build agents.

To be future-proof, the Job should not rely on a Docker API being available on the build agent, since there is no Docker daemon when building in a pod on a k8s cluster. For this scenario, there are several solutions available (e.g., [buildah|https://github.com/containers/buildah]), but [*kaniko*|https://github.com/GoogleContainerTools/kaniko] is usually recommended.

h2. Acceptance Criteria

* There is a Job that is triggered as soon as the HEAD of any branch in our GitLab repo is updated.
* The Job builds at least one image from a Dockerfile in our repo.
* The image is built inside a container that has no access to a Docker daemon.
* If the branch is {{main}}, the resulting image is pushed to a container registry, authenticated as a service user.
* A DevOps team dev can pull the image from the container registry.

For this scenario, there are several solutions available (e.g., [buildah|https://github.com/containers/buildah]), but *[kaniko|https://github.com/GoogleContainerTools/kaniko]* is usually recommended.

items.fromString:
We currently have one cluster that isn't even used by anyone except for us, but it still contains sensitive data that should not be accessed by (anyone, or anyone outside the team), most probably all of them being a {{Secret}} or a {{{}SealedSecret{}}}.

Also, we have unrestricted access for anyone to every namespace and {{kubeapi}} feature.

We must establish access control before anyone uses any of our (one) clusters productively.

This task is mostly about exploring/spreading/establishing knowledge about the following points:
 * How does RBAC work?
 * Is there anything for us to configure cluster-wide in order to enable apps to use RBAC?
 * Are there any restrictions we should impose globally, like setting up namespaces for teams to use?
 * Should we restrict access to some namespaces to be used by the DevOps teams only?

Note that RBAC should be a prerequisite for anyone to use a cluster productively. We should not encourage any team A to use a Kubernetes cluster, when any _other_ team B can accidentally delete resources of team B.

h2. Acceptance Criteria

A proper Helm chart for PSIwms should contain a landing page.
h2. Rationale:
 * Some of our documentation is relevant for users of the training environment. They should not be forced to navigate to our repo or website, or CollabSpace, or the PSIwms repo, or anywhere else, when it could just be deployed with the app itself.
 * PSIwms comes with a range of clients; a landing page could just present a link to all of them. This is actually how modern services should be presented: One starting point, and everything useful can be found from there.

items.fromString:
PSIwms comes with a wide range of clients, one of which is used for configuration only: The "project console", basically a terminal with commands tailored to change the configuration of a PSIwms server and do some maintenance work:
 * The {{ts}} command is used to start a task
 * The {{tls}} command is used to list existing tasks
 * (318 other commands)

A terminal is not what you'd expect in an app in a Kubernetes cluster, but this client isn't going anywhere any time soon.

We want to demonstrate that this client can still be incorporated in a Kubernetes environment. We want to add a pod to our example PSIwms app that serves that terminal. There are several ways to approach this:
 * The pod runs {{{}novnc{}}}, and a user can then open a remote desktop connection to this service. Upon connection, you are greeted by a terminal window.
 * The pod runs a terminal emulator directly, and you can connect to it via browser.

In both approaches, the pod would connect to the running PSIwms server pod, opening a terminal session there, using one of these approaches:
 * Via {{kubectl exec <PSIwms server pod name> /bin/bash}} (heavily preferred)
 * Via SSH (would require the PSIwms server pod to run {{{}sshd{}}}, bad!)

Note that in both approaches, the user could invoke the connection command directly with appropriate access right. We do not want to offer this to users, who should to everything in the browser. However, it might be possible to *split this story* here, by first creating a session as described directly from a dev machine, with appropriate documentation, and then add a pod that does it for the user later. If we split, *this* story is about having it all in the browser; put smaller parts of it into new tickets.

If we established RBAC before this story is tackled, we also have to make sure that the terminal pod has the appropriate permissions to {{kubectl exec}} on another pod, so we could then put the permission stuff on a separate ticket, too. As it stands now, there will be no RBAC by the end of the next sprint, which is Sprint 3.
h2. Acceptance Criteria:
 * execute any of the spu tools
 ** tls (task list)?
 ** ts (task start)?
 * (Actual WMS server running, Oracle DB)
 * separate service for console access → this is a client! only opens a session on WMS server container
 * visualization of output

h2. Acceptance Criteria:

items.fromString:
We need a way to let other teams integrate their development infrastructure with centrally managed infrastructure like a Git server (like GitLab), a GitOps platform (like ArgoCD), a Maven Repository Manager or Container Registry (like Nexus), and others.

We want to do so in a self-service way, and we also want to bring k8s closer to other teams. Given these circumstances, [Kubernetes Resource Controllers and Custom Resource|https://kubernetes.io/docs/concepts/extend-kubernetes/api-extension/custom-resources/] might be a good way to achieve integration.

It would work like this:
 * We announce in our cluster that there is a new, custom type of resources, e.g., a {{Product}}, using a CRD. It is now deploy {{Product}} type resources to our cluster, according to the schema we specified, so it could contain a name a Git repo URL.
 * We deploy a pod that acts as the Resource Controller for this new type of resource, e.g., a {{ProductController}}.
 * Whenever some team deploys a resource of that type, the Resource Controller automatically acts upon that new resource. In our example, when a {{Product}} is deployed, the {{ProductController}} would automatically add the Git repo as a repository to ArgoCD via its REST API.
 * Similarly, the Resource Controller would pick up all changes to a resource of its resource type, and perform the other CRUD operations accordingly.

The linked documentation specifies when you should or should not use a CRD and a Resource Controller. By the end of the sprint, we should have a much better understanding whether we want to use this setup for any integration we want to provide.

Examples:
 * A {{PipelineJobController}} might manage Jenkins Jobs according to the {{PipelineJob}} resource deployed in the cluster.
 * A {{ProductController}} might manage a development environment for a Product team when a {{Product}} is deployed in the cluster. In a very general approach, a {{Product}} would consist of a group name (used to deduce a k8s namespace), a Git repo URL, and a pointer to a Helm chart that describes all the services needed by the team, like its own Jenkins, and a set of {{PipelineJob}} resources. The controller could then integrate with ArgoCD (adding the Git repo), Nexus (granting write access to the team's Jenkins for artifacts in the {{Product}}'s group), GitLab (no obvious use case?) and Jira (no obvious use case?).

h2. Acceptance Criteria

The following criteria are probably best achieved by a short presentation to the team, and the presentation should best be placed ("as code") in the repo, but this is not mandatory to finish the task.
 * The team can confidently decide whether CRDs and Resource Controllers are the right tool for scenarios as explained above.
 * The team can confidently estimate the amount of work required to set up a Resource Controller.

items.fromString:
We already created Docker images in our first sprints, and we will create many more in the future. So far, every dev who worked with those images just built them locally themselves, and they were also pushed manually to Nexus.

Instead, this should be done by a Job, so the images age built and pushed automatically, depending on the branch that was changed.

For building images with no Docker daemon available, see DEVOPS-79.
h2. Acceptance Criteria
 * There is a Job that is triggered as soon as the HEAD of any branch in our GitLab repo is updated.
 * The Job builds at least one image from a Dockerfile in our repo.
 * If the branch is {{{}main{}}}, the resulting image is pushed to a container registry, authenticated as a service user.
 * A DevOps team dev can pull the image from the container registry.

For building images with no Docker daemon available, see DEVOPS-79. For building the image, you can choose any tool you like; Docker daemon ({{{}docker build{}}}) is probably the most simple and fast one.
h2. Acceptance Criteria

items.fromString:
We want to make PSIwms available for deployment in a training environment. In order to keep things simple, we first want to make sure that we can orchestrate it locally. For this, we need two things:
 * a PSIwms image, see DEVOPS-71
 * a local example Helm chart

We do not require the image to be configurable in any way. One image with a fixed configuration is fine.

*Acceptance criteria:*
 * There is a Helm chart in our repo for PSIwms.
 * There is documentation on how to deploy this Helm chart to a k8s cluster.
 * Executing on that documentation on a local k8s cluster, e.g. in Rancher, results in a running PSIwms app.
 * As soon as deployment is finished, the state of all components of the app is OK.
 * There is documentation on how to query the health check API endpoint of PSIwms.
 * Executing on that documentation on the deployed PSIwms app results in a proper response from PSIwms server.

items.fromString:
We want to make PSIsrs (an example setup) available for deployment in a training environment. In order to keep things simple, we first want to make sure that we can deploy it locally. For this, we need two things:
 * a PSIsrs image, see DEVOPS-69
 * a local example Helm chart

We do not require the image to be configurable in any way. One image with a fixed routing graph and configuration, including routing profiles, is fine.

Acceptance criteria:
 * There is a Helm chart in our repo for PSIsrs.
 * There is documentation on how to deploy this Helm chart to a k8s cluster.
 * Executing on that documentation on a local k8s cluster, e.g. in Rancher, results in a running PSIsrs app.
 * As soon as deployment is finished, the state of all components of the app is OK.
 * There is documentation on how to query the app for an example route.
 * If additional information is required to compose such an example query, this info is provided by the deployed app (e.g. via {{/example}} endpoint or similar).
 * Executing on that documentation results in a response from PSIsrs containing an example route.

items.fromString:
We want to demonstrate that training environments can be used to deploy real apps, but we need a dockerized app for that. LOG is not there yet, and dockerizing LOG apps is out of scope for this team, but in order to demonstrate, we want to dockerize this very simple app. PSIsrs just needs to be unpacked and startet with a very simple configuration file and some data.

In a first step, we just want to create the PSIsrs docker image. In order to create it, we need the following:
 * PSIsrs binary
 * PSIsrs configuration
 * Map data for PSIsrs to operate on, i.e., a routing graph

For the latter, any geographical region should be fine for demonstration purposes. We also do not care about the routing profile, anything is fine.
h2. Acceptance criteria
 * There is a Dockerfile in our repo with build instructions for a PSIsrs image.
 * There is documentation in our repo on how to build the image.
 * Executing on that documentation results in a PSIsrs image on the local machine.
 * There is documentation in our repo on how to instantiate a container from that image.
 * Executing on that documentation results in a PSIsrs container locally.
 * The container exposes a port.
 * There is documentation on how to perform an example query on that port.
 * Executing on that documentation results in a response from the PSIsrs container containing a route.

items.fromString:
We deployed training environments containing generic "apps", just showing one static page. PSIsrs allows for some actual interaction by exposing an HTTP API.

For development of the PSIsrs image, see DEVOPS-69. For development of the PSIsrs Helm chart, see DEVOPS-70. For adding PSIsrs to the app selection list on ArgoCD, see DEVOPS-67.
h2. Acceptance criteria
 * Confirming the provisioning of a training environment with PSIsrs selected actually results in a PSIsrs service being deployed.
 * As soon as deployment is finished, the state of all components of the app is OK.
 * There is documentation on how to query the app for an example route.
 * If additional information is required to compose an example query, this info is provided by the deployed app (e.g. via {{/example}} endpoint or similar).
 * Executing on that documentation results in a response from PSIsrs containing an example route.

customfield_10020.goal: Deploy an app containing a LOG image from Gitlab to k8s cluster in a cloud via web service

items.fromString:
Acceptance criteria:
 * When deploying an app in a training environment, release branches can be selected as the version.
 * Given an app deployed in a training environment with a release branch selected as its version, when new commits are merged to the release channel, the app is updated automatically.
items.toString:
Release branches can be regarded as release channels from a user perspective. Users who choose a release channel, instead of a fixed version, want to see changes to that release channel automatically.

In order for this to work in our current environment, GitLab has to inform ArgoCD about changes appropriately.

Acceptance criteria:
 * When deploying an app in a training environment, release branches can be selected as the version.
 * Given an app deployed in a training environment with a release branch selected as its version, when new commits are merged to the release channel, the app is updated automatically.

Acceptance criteria:

According to this team's principles, it should be self-service, without the need to request something from us or waiting for us.

 h2.Acceptance Criteria

items.fromString:
We started out deploying training environments into a VPC in IBM Cloud, but in comparison, AWS is much more mature when it comes to clean APIs and integration of their different services. Mid-term, we want to shift as much as possible from IBM Cloud to AWS.

For this, we first need to be able to log into AWS as a team.

Currently, [~accountid:712020:02e768f3-b000-492d-8df8-887fd1ebffb4] is the only one who can create accounts for us, but he requested assistance from someone of our team with AWS IAM experience.

*Acceptance criteria:*
 * Every team member has their own AWS account.
 * Every team member is able to log in with their own AWS account.
 * Every team member changed their initial password (table below).
 * Every team member activated multi-factor authentication (table below).

||Hero||Password changed||MFA activated||
|Christian|(/)|(/)|
|Denis|(/)|(/)|
|Jan|(/)|(/)|
|Łukasz|(/)|(/)|
|Przemek|(/)| |
|Tobias|(/)|(/)|

items.fromString:
Currently, documentation about (and probably scripts for) our infrastructure, especially in FFM DC 2.1, is scattered across several repositories in groups and subgroups in GitLab. Working on this documentation should be easy inside an IDE, but IDEs are much better at switching folders instead of repos. It is also much harder to make consistent changes across several repos, and if we have dependencies between repositories, we would also have to version those. Also, if we find that the current structure is suboptimal, restructuring it would require creating/moving/deleting whole repositories, which is not version-controlled and not code-reviewed.

All this becomes much easier if we consolidate all those repos into our main {{devops}} repo, into appropriate folders. For starters, we can simply replicate {{group/subgroup/repo}} inside our {{devops}} repo as folders {{{}folder/subfolder/subsubfolder{}}}.

This ticket is only about consolidation. If we find afterwards that some kind of cleanup is required, e.g., using a different folder structure, we can do this in a separate ticket.

*Acceptance criteria:*
 * The {{devops}} repo contains all documentation that is currently scattered over several repositories.
 * All those other repositories and the groups that only contain those repositories are removed.
 * There is only one single repo containing docs/scripts for FFM DC 2.1 infrastructure.

items.fromString:
We need a way to deploy apps in a LOG environment in single and bulk mode. We want to provide a way for Ops to start one or many training environments. Notification in this case should be sent to ?environment's end users?. 

Note for estimations: We assume that we do have a configurable Helm chart for this task available when the task is started, but we do not have any proper UI to interact with LOG training environment.
h2. Acceptance criteria
 * For app templates provided by product/project team the Ops is able to select proper app for one or multiple environments at once..
 * After deploying a selected app , having specified at least the required configuration options, and starting the deployment, running environment is available for end-user (check status, provide URL) and additionally notification is sent via email/Teams after env is available.
 * If the app cannot be deployed due to some problem, nothing is deployed and the user who requested the deployment is notified.
items.toString:
For development of the PSIwms image, see DEVOPS-71. For development of the PSIwms Helm chart, see DEVOPS-72.
h2. Acceptance criteria
 * When provisioning a training environment via ArgoCD, there is an entry for PSIwms in the list of available apps.
 * Deploying a training environment with PSIwms selected does not necessarily result in a running PSIwms app, see DEVOPS-6.
 * Any notification to the user upon finished deployment is not part of this ticket.

items.fromString:
After releasing a version of the application, it should be available for selection automatically. This automation will streamline the workflow, ensuring that the app is seamlessly integrated into the selection process without manual intervention. This means that we need a Jenkins pipeline that creates Docker containers from the checked-in code. There should also be a check that the containers can also be deployed.

Acceptance criteria:
 * Upon completion of the app development or update, the app is automatically added to the selection pool for deployment without requiring manual intervention.
 * If the app meets all necessary criteria for deployment, it becomes immediately available for selection in the deployment configuration.
 * If the app does not meet the required criteria for deployment, appropriate feedback is provided to the team.

This automation will streamline the workflow, ensuring that the app is seamlessly integrated into the selection process without manual intervention. This means that we need a Jenkins pipeline that creates Docker containers from the checked-in code. There should also be a check that the containers can also be deployed.

Acceptance criteria:

Upon completion of the app development or update, the app is automatically added to the selection pool for deployment without requiring manual intervention.

If the app meets all necessary criteria for deployment, it becomes immediately available for selection in the deployment configuration.

If the app does not meet the required criteria for deployment, appropriate feedback is provided to the team.

items.fromString:
We want a second Kubernetes environment on AWS. We also want to provide a mechanism that allows the user to specify in which environment (AWS or LOG env) they want to deploy the app. 

For the future, we should use Terraform as an infrastructure-as-code tool for versioning, reuse and sharing. Therefore, the Kubernetes cluster should be deployed on AWS via Terraform files.

 

Prerequisite:

-Credentials for AWS

 

Acceptance criteria:

AWS EKS is up and running.

When submitting the deployment configuration of an application, there is a defined location to specify the environment.

The application gets deployed in the correct environment.

The submitter receives feedback as to whether the application has been deployed.

 

Useful Links:

[https://registry.terraform.io/modules/terraform-aws-modules/eks/aws/latest]

[https://registry.terraform.io/providers/hashicorp/kubernetes/latest/docs]

[https://registry.terraform.io/modules/terraform-aws-modules/vpc/aws/latest]

 

Example Terraform files in "Attachments"

customfield_10020.goal: Set up ArgoCD in a new k8s cluster to deploy a sample mockup app described as a Helm chart

items.fromString:
We need a generic means to configure the apps deployed in a LOG environment. We want to provide a mechanism to specify key-value pairs when deploying an app, that has some effect on the deployed app. For example, the deployment might be implemented using a Helm chart that selects the Docker image tag depending on one configuration option, and conditionally include some pods depending on another one.

Note for estimations: We assume that we do not have a configurable Helm chart for this task available when the task is started, so creating an appropriate one would be part of this task.
h2. Acceptance criteria
 * For app templates provided by their product/project team in an automated way, the team has some way to specify configuration options for the app.
 * After selecting an app in the end-user interface, the end-user can see all configuration options specified for an app.
 * After selecting an app in the end-user interface, the end-user can specify all required configuration options.
 * After deploying a selected app in the end-user interface, having specified at least the required configuration options, and starting the deployment, the configuration values specified take a visible effect on the app.
 * If the app cannot be deployed due to some problem related to the submitted configuration, nothing is deployed and the user who requested the deployment is notified.
items.toString:
_As a QA person, I want to have a generic way to configure the app deployed in my training environment._

We need a generic means to configure the apps deployed in a LOG environment. We want to provide a mechanism to specify key-value pairs when deploying an app, that has some effect on the deployed app. For example, the deployment might be implemented using a Helm chart that selects the Docker image tag depending on one configuration option, and conditionally include some pods depending on another one.

Note for estimations: We assume that we do not have a configurable Helm chart for this task available when the task is started, so creating an appropriate one would be part of this task.

h2. Acceptance criteria

* For app templates provided by their product/project team in an automated way, the team has some way to specify configuration options for the app.
* After selecting an app in the end-user interface, the end-user can see all configuration options specified for an app.
* After selecting an app in the end-user interface, the end-user can specify all required configuration options.
* After deploying a selected app in the end-user interface, having specified at least the required configuration options, and starting the deployment, the configuration values specified take a visible effect on the app.
* If the app cannot be deployed due to some problem related to the submitted configuration, nothing is deployed and the user who requested the deployment is notified.

items.fromString:
We want to efficiently locate and access information about existing training environments. Such a dashboard should be easily accessible. There should be an option to navigate to a particular environment and possibly access individual applications.

 

Acceptance criteria:
 * Ability to access the dashboard and view all existing training environments.
 * For a given environment, it is possible to check detailed information.
 * For a given environment, I can get links, go to a given application.

items.fromString:
We want the ability to remove training environments when it is no longer needed. This feature will enhance the flexibility and efficiency of our development and testing processes by allowing users to clean up resources that are no longer required. We need to make sure that the environmental removal process is complete and leaves no residue. We need to ensure that the user initiating the removal process is authenticated and has the necessary permissions to delete the training environment.

 

Acceptance criteria:
 * After the removal action has been triggered, the environment is fully removed and is no longer available for use.
 * After deletion of the environment, a notification is sent that the action has been correctly completed.
 * There is a confirmation mechanism to prevent accidental deletions.

We need a easy way to deploy apps in a LOG environment. We want to provide a GUI to be used by eg. QA employee when deploying an app.

Note for estimations: We assume that we do have a configurable Helm chart for this task available when the task is started, but we do not have any proper GUI to interact with LOG training environment.

Acceptance criteria:
 * For app templates provided by product/project team the QA is able to select proper app in end-user interface.
 * After deploying a selected app in the end-user interface, having specified at least the required configuration options, and starting the deployment, running environment is available for user id GUI (check status, provide URL) and additionally notification is sent via email/Teams after env is available.
 * If the app cannot be deployed due to some problem, nothing is deployed and the user who requested the deployment is notified.

items.fromString:
We need a simple service to
 * start a java app as a http service (eg via noVNC - like console service.) (test/trainingdemo usecase)

the PSIwms Desktop Client.
h2. Acceptance Criteria
 * The user must be able to get the PSIwms Desktop Client easily.
 * WMS client has to be preconfigured to use in the personal training environment
 * WMS client runs successful against training environment
 * user can see configurations from the given WMS client
 * Get help in the event of an error

customfield_10020.goal: Complete PSIwms helm chart (client's java + web) with the view to moving to Google Cloud

items.toString:
We deployed training environments containing very simple apps. Our stakeholders are much more interested in seeing it all in action with an app that is actively developed by us.

We want to showcase this with a simple orchestration that contains PSIwms.

For development of the PSIwms image, see DEVOPS-71. For development of the PSIwms Helm chart, see DEVOPS-72. For adding PSIwms to the app selection list on ArgoCD, see DEVOPS-18.
h2. Acceptance criteria
 * Confirming the provisioning of a training environment with PSIwms selected actually results in a PSIwms service being deployed.
 * As soon as deployment is finished, the state of all components of the app is OK.
 * There is documentation on how to query the app for its health status.
 * Executing on that documentation results in a response from the PSIwms instance deployed in the training environment about its health status.

items.fromString:
Acceptance criteria:
 * When submitting the deployment configuration of an app to be deployed in a LOG environment, there is a defined place to specify the app's version.
 * When submitting the deployment configuration of an app in a LOG environment with the app's version specified, if the specified version exists, the specified version of the app is deployed.
 * When submitting the deployment configuration of an app in a LOG environment with the app's version specified, if the specified version does not exist, the request is rejected and nothing is deployed.
 * When a deployment configuration of an app in a LOG environment is rejected because of a problem concerning a specified app version, the user who requested the deployment is notified.
items.toString:

 * When submitting the deployment configuration of an app to be deployed in a LOG environment, there is a defined place to specify the app's version.

 * When submitting the deployment configuration of an app in a LOG environment with the app's version specified, if the specified version does not exist, the request is rejected.
 * When a deployment configuration of an app in a LOG environment is rejected because of a problem related to a specified app version, nothing is deployed and the user who requested the deployment is notified.

items.fromString:
We need a common way for OPs to choose an app that will be deployed in the training environment.

For this an OPs editing some configurations/values of an helm chart and pushing it to the system (argoCD/K8s?).

The system will then start an deployment with the given configurations.

For the first draft we should use a helm chart mockup

{*}Acceptance Criteria{*}:
 * The system shall provide a user interface (CLI?) accessible to OPs for selecting the application to be deployed.
 * Upon selection, the chosen application's deployment process shall be initiated automatically by the system.
 * The system shall confirm successful deployment of the chosen application within the training environment.
 * In case of any errors or failures during deployment, the system shall provide detailed error messages to assist OPs in troubleshooting and resolving deployment issues.

Unsure about:
 * The system shall maintain a log of all deployment activities, including the application chosen, deployment start time, completion time, and any relevant status updates or errors encountered.
 * OPs shall have the ability to roll back the deployment of the chosen application in the event of unforeseen issues or errors post-deployment.

items.fromString:
There is a diverse range of LOG employees who have to work in a training environment regularly:
 * Sales people want to demonstrate our software to new customers.
 * QA people want to look for rough edges in the latest version of our software.
 * New employees want to get familiar with our software without fear to break anything.

The current process to provision a training environment for WMS comprises various teams (the requestor, maybe Assistence, Infra, Academy), the workflow is not documented anywhere although it contains a lot of manual steps, and there is no tool support to promote the workflow.

After a training is completed, the training environment has to be cleaned up, which brings its own set of undocumented workflows, and manual steps.

We want to:
 * drastically reduce the teams involved in the provisioning of training environments, ideally to the requestor only.
 * drastically reduce the amount of manual steps for training environment management.
items.toString:
_As a LOG employee, I want to provision my own WMS training environment._

There is a diverse range of LOG employees who have to work in a training environment regularly:

* Sales people want to demonstrate our software to new customers.
* QA people want to look for rough edges in the latest version of our software.
* New employees want to get familiar with our software without fear to break anything.

The current process to provision a training environment for WMS comprises various teams (the requestor, maybe Assistence, Infra, Academy), the workflow is not documented anywhere although it contains a lot of manual steps, and there is no tool support to promote the workflow.

After a training is completed, the training environment has to be cleaned up, which brings its own set of undocumented workflows, and manual steps.

We want to:

* drastically reduce the teams involved in the provisioning of training environments, ideally to the requestor only.
* drastically reduce the amount of manual steps for training environment management.
